answers.author: Matthew Reges
answers.text:
Yes, cautiously. The formal requirements for our leadership positions do not appear to present a hard barrier.
Our department head job descriptions show a mix. Several of them have language which would likely exclude Millenials: "8-10 years senior executive management experience." Others have looser language like, "Extensive experience in public finance administration, and considerable experience at a supervisory level" or looser yet, "Extensive professional experience in a responsible position in the public works field." It's not hard to imagine an IT Director aged 34 with a CS BS and an MBA, and a mix of  municipal programming and start-up management experience.
At the level of assistant department head, requirements ranges from "five years' professional experience and two years' supervisory" to a looser, "extensive supervisory and administrative experience." A 32-year old with a degree, five years' line work and five years' supervisory work could be a strong candidate for these positions.
Elected office is another route. In Virginia, voters select the sheriff, treasurer, lead prosecutor, and other department-head equivalent positions with significant roles in city and county government. The requirements to run for office do not include years of experience. Our new treasurer is a notable young leader in the organization. 
How does this compare to other states?

answers.author: Larry Burks
answers.text:
Rick,
Thanks for posing the question. I would like to clarify my understanding of succession planning. Not that I disagree with your question, but a healthy succession plan does not require a specific amount of management level job openings. However, a healthy SP does require significant levels of management level job training. So, I would propose a second question, "Does your organization or jurisdiction have a significant amount of training or mentoring to prepare (or qualify) Millennials currently hired for future management positions?"

author: Rick Aronhalt
text:
Do you have enough management-level job openings in your jurisdiction available to the Millennial Generation (ages 17 to 34) to ensure a healthy succession plan? 
I am asking this question because we are researching our December web workshop on succession planning and bridging the generational gap between Baby Boomers and Millennials in local government. We are finding that the number of actual positions for which Millennials can qualify -- due to requirements for years of experience -- is incredibly low. I am wondering if other jurisdictions are noticing the same trend.
title: Job openings for Millennials
